description: From Middle English pestel, pestell, from Old French pestel, from Latin pistillum, from pīnsō (“pound, beat”). Doublet of pistil.

entries.meaning: A club-shaped, round-headed stick used in a mortar to pound, crush, rub or grind things.
(archaic) A constable's or bailiff's staff; so called from its shape.
examples: […] whether the chopping-knife or their pestles were the better weapons

entries.meaning: The leg and leg bone of an animal, especially of a pig.

verbs.description: pestle (third-person singular simple present pestles, present participle pestling, simple past and past participle pestled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To pound, crush, rub or grind, as in a mortar with a pestle.
